Comment: But I was told that attacking books at school libraries wasn't an issue because you could just buy the book.   This is what is so frustrating about these types of issues. You get people to agree to a water-downed version of your idea, and then expand it way past what those people signed up for.   And this does happen. All the time. I know a lot of people just assume everyone is always in on the end goal, but people do get tricked by this kind of stuff.  You start with a surface level argument. "There are obscene books that young kids shouldn't have access to." You may not agree with that, but it doesn't really matter. A lot of people do as a very blanket statement. Like the average person would say erotica  shouldn't be in a school. And in a store it should be sectioned off where kids can't access. And please note I understand that this stuff is being used to target LGBT material as 'obscene', but that is kind of my point. You start out with being generalized. Some people will get the dog whistle, but they aren't really important. You already have them for your cause. You are looking to try and convince the general public. Random parent isn't really going to be like 'Ya, fuck LGBT books' (Some definitely are, but again, not really talking about them). But a random parent is more likely to be 'Well, yes, of course I don't want my little Timmy to have access to smut', without really considering what they are thinking about is not the same thing these laws are targeting.
